confusion_points: 5.5x2.1mm and 5.5x2.5mm look nearly identical but 2.1mm plugs are loose in 2.5mm jacks
Center positive vs center negative - ALWAYS check polarity before connecting, wrong polarity can destroy devices
Voltage is not standardized - a 12V device on a 19V adapter will likely be damaged
Same size connector does NOT mean compatible - check voltage, current, AND polarity
Barrel jacks have no keying or protection against wrong polarity/voltage
EIAJ standardized sizes exist but most manufacturers ignore them
Many universal adapters come with multiple tips but selecting wrong voltage is dangerous
buying_guide: ALWAYS match voltage (exact), polarity (center positive/negative), current (adapter must meet or exceed device requirement), AND physical size. When in doubt, measure your existing adapter with calipers. Universal adapters are convenient but risky - triple-check settings. Consider switching to USB-C PD for new projects.
notes: Barrel connectors are one of the most frustrating connector types due to complete lack of standardization. Dozens of sizes exist, polarity varies by manufacturer, and voltage ranges from 3V to 48V. The only way to know compatibility is to check all specifications. Despite this chaos, they remain common because they're cheap, simple, and adequate for low-power DC applications. USB-C Power Delivery is slowly replacing them.

sources.name: CUI Devices DC Power Connector Guide
